ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course strengthened what we began in the first course of the sequence: it focused on Russian grammar, as well as spent a bit more time on culture through more short stories and movies. It improved my reading, writing, and speaking
spekaing, reading, and writing in russian; i learnt how to do presentations in russian.
I was able to increase my ability to learn, read, write, and speak in Russian. This was immensely helpful as the course was led as a discussion, allowing students to learn from each other.
Learned to improve my Russian reading and writing
Russian grammar, reading and writing but at an accommodated level given my previous knowledge

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is well suited to teaching people who already speak Russian how to hone their skills. I think the course was a bit unorganized (ie all canvas homework slots were blank so I never really knew which places to put my homework), and the workload on a day to day basis seemed uneven. I think some times I wasnt quite sure what we were learning. In general, however the course was great and I learned a lot
strenghts - the size of the class, the TA, the books we read. this class just throws you into the deep nad helps you to really learn and imporve your russian.

This course was designed to increase discussion  it was helpful when we held conversations and were corrected to better speak. All assignments were carefully graded to learn from mistakes. There could be better review of work after we submit it in class  some mistakes were difficult to understand until discussed further.
I wish this course was a little more organized, sometimes it felt we switched from topic to topic and how we were switching didn't make sense

Introduction or revisiting of Russian movies and stories that I loved as a child or understood but not very much in-depth! A weakness in this course is perhaps the pace, there were some grammar topics that flew past me, but honestly, I was always able to communicate difficulties and the professors knew how to level with students because it is a heritage speakers course and it is inevitable that not everyone will have the same comfort with all topics

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual lectures were there by necessity, but I think they make a language class much harder
it was all good
It was the best it could be.
I suppose the only thing that suffered was not being able to look at cursive handwriting but great transition nonetheless!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, this course is definitely a must take for people who speak Russian at home- it improves skills very quickly. I came in to the first course not being able to read and left being able to write essays.

absolutely! I would have never learnt so much in other russian class. this class is perfect for people with slavic backgrpunds. it just makes learing russian so much easier. the teacher and the ta were amazing - always willing to meet and great at explaing things multiple times and in differnt wys if something wasn't clear. i love the class it wassuper fun, and i get to watch russian movies and read actual books. i love tht we learn from primary sources and not just form a random textbook.
Yes! This course truly helps you expand your Russian and the TF and Professor made sure to cater to your needs.

Yes! I'd recommend this course to anyone who grew up speaking Russian and wants to improve/formalize their level of the language - Prof Titus is very good at adjusting to your experience even if you haven't learned to read at the beginning of semester one
For Heritage students, this is a good continuation of the Russ 142a course from the fall.
It is a lot of consistent homework and assignments, I always had work for the class. But the professors are really kind and it was the type of work that I never felt bad or intimidated by

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: office hours
n/a
